Posts.Content: Oct 14, 2008 07:05PM Katiejane wrote:   Drea,  When I first started rads, I used aloe vera gel and aquaphor cream.  The aloe was great but once my skin began to break down I couldn't stand to use the aquaphor because it was so heavy and sticky/gooey. It kept the area too moist and would cause the top layer (or 2) of skin to come right off leaving raw areas.  I found a product, Pure Emu Oil that worked wonders!!!  It penetrates 3 cell layers deep which promotes healing.  My Rad Onc, Surgeon, and Oncologist are really impressed with the way I have healed and the lack of scarring. I still use it on my bilat. mastectomy scars and the skin that had broken down with Rads. that is now healed with no scars.  Everyone seems to have their favorites and I did try several different products.  Good luck in your search.
Posts.Title: Best oil to protect skin during rads? Drea S3K5

Posts.Content: Jul 19, 2012 02:30PM Katiejane wrote:   I have a Flexi pump and I was never happy with it.  I am a small built person(5'4" 120-130 lbs) and the garments that came with the pump seemed to be for larger framed people.  Therefore, the garments never did fit right and I ended up w/ more swelling in certain places than I did before I used the pump!  Everyone is different and as we all know, what works for one doesn't always work for the other.  I know of people that the Flexi works well for. Also, I am a very active person and had a hard time finding time in my day to use the pump.  It is time consuming in my opinion.  Now that I've had DIEP reconstruction, use of a pump is a big No-No! So, mine sits in the storage room upstairs!  MLD works best for me!  Good luck with your decision! Katiejane

Posts.Title: Chest X Ray - Shadow on Lung esserbre esserbre

Posts.Content: Jul 25, 2009 05:00PM Katiejane wrote:    Pam,   I had a bilateral mast. with 5 nodes removed on my non diseased side.  After several months I found a lump in this armpit-about the size of a medium oblong grape. I immediately went to my surgeon, totally freaked out that the Ca had returned. It was an enlarged node that I have since learn to drain with massage.  It was clogged and in-turn filled with lymph fluid.  It was firm to the touch but moved around alot(was not fixed to one spot). My cancer side also had lumps under my arm. They were as hard as a rock and did not move when I touched them. Also, they were not tender to the touch as the other node was. I would get in to see my surgeon if I were you but please try not to panic.  I know this is easier said then done!  As far as the IV'S go, I had anesthesia put mine in my neck just to avoid all arm punctures. I really couldn't guess if this is secondary to the IV's. I hope this will help alittle but I'd certainly call my Doc on Monday!  Good luck!
Posts.Title: Armpit Lump in Good Arm...Clog or bc? Dejaboo Dejaboo

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2008 07:51PM Katiejane wrote: esserbre,  I also had a mastectomy, chemo, and rads this past summer.  I was told by my Rad. Onc. that the very upper part of the R lung was going to get some of the Rads. and that there was no way to prevent the exposure. So in the future, I may show shadows in a chest x-ray-just some scaring from rads.!  It's all a trade off I guess and we, as our own advocates must decide which is the best/ worst of the evils!  I just had my 1st 3 month check/pet scan-they say there is a small nodule in the upper lobe of my R lung.  It didn't glow which means it's not Cancer but it sure makes me nervous!!! Is it headed that way??? Guess I'll know in 3 months

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 08:45PM - edited Oct 2, 2008 08:46PM by Katiejane Hi Angie,   I use the Crystal stick as well simply because it's natural with no man made chemicals.  I then put Shower to Shower body powder on my pits immediately after deod. application.  The Crystal stick has no aluminum chlorhydrate(sp?) which is the antiperspirant part of a deodorant and it helps to keep me dry---My armpit skin is very sensitive and this, along with alittle corn starch keeps it from sticking together and prevents chaffing of the skin.  Katiejane

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2008 08:26PM Katiejane wrote: Liz,  I finished Rads. in Nov. of '07 and had alot of chest tightness--between a bilateral and 25 rads........!!  It felt like a tight band around my chest area, front and back. I never thought I would get use to the feel of my "new normal".  They told me it was scar tissue, which makes sense since rads. cause burns/scaring internally and the scar tissue caused by the surgery itself. Physical therapy was prescribed-I learned alot of stretches & ROM exercises. My PT also did some work on the "cording" that developed in my armpit & down my upper arm. I do these stretches everyday(when I remember!) and it has really helped. Good luck and I hope this helps you!

Posts.Title: Carpal Tunnel Syndrome With Lymphedema Anyone??? Katiejane Binney4

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2008 03:56PM Katiejane wrote: Binney,   Thank you for taking the time to sit down and address my issues!  Yes, I am very frustrated because no one has told me any thing about what a Therapy Intensive is and I'm supposedly going to a Cancer Rehab. Center(Navitas)!  I have the compression sleeve and glove which they measured me for and they have shown me once or twice how to massage but I have never had an actual LE massage.  It has been a real fight with my insurance company to get PT and Psychological counseling covered.  Now that the new year has arrived, they say they will no longer cover the counseling! And they have never covered the LE part either. The LE therapist they have there use to be in PT and decided to change to LE therapy.  I have never felt much confidence in her as she has little experience and seems to second guess everything she does.  When I ask my oncologist where I can find a LE Therapist, he refers me to Navitas as they are all in the same building-different businesses but that's the only referral I've been able to get from him.  No one seems to have any info on LE management.  This tells you how little this issue is addressed! Anything I can do to manage this mess I am more than willing to do but the lack of available treatment facilities makes me feel like I'm beating my head against the wall!!!! I guess I will try to start networking within my community to see if I can come up with some other options.  Thank you again Binney.  I really thought I was doing a fair job managing this LE.  LOL!!!!!!     Chattie

Posts.Content: Sep 10, 2011 10:51PM Katiejane wrote:   Hope,  I am still treating my 1st case of cellulitis which started on Sunday of Labor Day weekend.I woke that morning with a low grade fever and general aches. There was no redness anywhere on my arm. By 2 pm my arm(under compression sleeve) began to ache like like a bad bruise. When I removed the sleeve it was a bright reddish pink with spots that pretty much covered my entire arm. So I headed to the ER and they stared me on IV Ancef. I was allowed to go home but had a saline lock so that I could administer my own IV meds every 8 hours for 5 days. When the IV meds were done, I started on oral Keflex for another 5 days. You definitely need to be checked by a doctor and see your Le therapist. Do not treat this lightly as it can spread very quickly.  Hugs!  Katiejane

I hope you find what works for you and please share it with the rest of us! Katiejane

Posts.Title: Diagnosed 4 years ago now 16 year old niece has lump linreed Beesie

Posts.Content: Nov 24, 2008 02:49PM Katiejane wrote: Doe,  Boy, can I relate!!!  Clothing has become a challenge at times!  No more sweaters or "rough" fabrics for me anymore.  I had a bilateral with no reconstruction 6/07 .  I have tried all kinds of camisoles amongst other things and I cannot stand to have anything close to my skin. And forget bras and falsies!  The pressure from any type of garment that goes around my upper trunk rubs & puts pressure on my partially numb LE. After a few hours I feel like I am deeply bruised anywhere there has been pressure.  I live in the Rockies so warmth is important as our winters are very long and cold.  What works for me are the soft cotton knits and then I layer. Eddie Bauer has nice casual tops like this.  Also, I use cornstarch anywhere rubbing/chaffing will occur even in my armpits and under the silicone of my compression sleeves. Works alot better than body powder.  I believe competitive bicyclist use it because of the rubbing on the seats. I do hope you have no problems with the rash on your arm!      katiejane
Posts.Title: Clothing lionessdoe sccruiser

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2016 09:39PM Katiejane wrote: I really hope you don't get lymphedema!! I had 24 nodes removed on my diseased side, 4 on the non-diseased side. I developed LE within the first 3 months post mastectomy. As far as travel, sleeping on affected side etc., -I have always slept on my affected side even though it is not ideal. I continue to enjoy my 2 glasses of wine with dinner in the evening and I travel to see my family which is about a 14-15 hour day. I also had a lymph node transfer one year ago which has helped with my cellulitis infections. But I refuse to let this terrible LE dictate what I can and cannot enjoy in my life. I'm only going to get one go around here so I say do what works for you and keeps you comfortable and as close to your old normal as possible! Hugs and best wishes to you!

Posts.Content: May 12, 2010 04:21AM Katiejane wrote: Meg,  I have traveled x1 w/ my Flexi and I didn't dare check the pump.  I did check the garments and bought a small bag with wheels to pack the pump section in. I also had my  oncologist write me a note explaining the pump was a medical device just in case security gave me a problem.  It was no different than carrying on any other small bag. It was stored in the overhead bin.  There should be no problems! Katiejane

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2008 08:55PM Katiejane wrote: Hi Everyone,      I had my flu shot today and since I can't take it in either arm because of LE, I offered my thigh or my bottom.  The doc said it was ok to do either so I chose the behind so my thigh wouldn't get sore. No discomfort in my hip as of now.  Last year I also had the inoculation for pneumonia--also in the hip. I've been getting flu shots for approximately 12 years.
Posts.Title: Flu Shots DianeCA dreamwriter

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2011 08:10AM Katiejane wrote:   Ok ladies......I spoke with nuclear medicine today(where bone scans are done)  & exchanged info with one of the gentlemen who actually does the injection/scan. He was very kind and addressed my concerns with the injection. He acknowledged that my LE was a big concern and said he/they will not inject into either of my arms or hands. I do have a decent vein on my ankle and he was pleased to hear that!  He also said they have had to do the injection in the neck as well but preferred to save that one for in patients. He was very reassuring and thanked me for giving them a "heads up". It was so nice to speak to someone who has some knowledge of LE! Thank you all for your input and support!  Also, the amount of fluid injected for the scan is 1 ccor ml!!   Katiejane
Posts.Title: Bone Scan Next Week-Injection Katiejane Katiejane

One more question?  Has anyone heard of a compression sleeve made in Australia-maybe called "new skin"? Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2008 04:11AM Katiejane wrote: Jennifer,  I was hospitalized this week for uncontrolled hypertension as a result of thyroid damage from rads.  This has been one of my first experiences in dealing with IV's & blood draws in the foot.  B/P's in the leg haven't been a problem as everyone seems willing to give it a try with alittle direction.  They were much more hesitant to do the sticks in the foot.  It does hurt a bit more in your foot but it can be done successfully!!!! They were even willing to do it in my neck if need be.  But I pray I'm never in a situation where I can't speak up for myself because alot of them didn't know what my compression sleeves were and I wear a medical bracelet-not one person ever took a look at it!!!!!  Chattie

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2011 10:58AM Katiejane wrote: Well, I had the bone scan today and the scan itself is a piece of cake!!  And the guy who did my injection used a vein in my ankle!  :)  There were absolutely no problems! I was even able to watch the screen as the results(films) materialized. Very interesting!! I did have to do two follow up x-rays-one on my neck where I've had arthritis for years and one on each tibia/fibula. I have seen results of cancer + bone scans and this didn't appear to look anything like those but I am anxiously awaiting the "official" word from the radiologist. Keepin' my fingers crossed! katiejane
Posts.Title: Bone Scan Next Week-Injection Katiejane Katiejane

I guess the radiologist discovered bone splints (bilateral) in the tibia/fib area. Certainly not what I expected but certainly a very welcome diagnosis!!!!!!  And guess what caused these shin splints????  New custom orthotics(sp?) that I have been wearing on my 12 hours shifts! All I could do was laugh!!!! I've never heard of such a thing!  Anyway, thanks for all of your support!   Katiejane
Posts.Title: Bone Scan Next Week-Injection Katiejane Katiejane

Posts.Content: Jul 11, 2008 10:28AM - edited Jul 11, 2008 11:09AM by Katiejane Thought I'd add my 2 cents here----I work as a Nurse in a hospital and get this question all of the time from patients and family.  I tell them the truth--it's a result of BC/surgery.  I'm not offended nor do I feel the need to become defensive when they ask-- it's human curiosity.  I use it as an opportunity to "educate" people-how else are they to know unless they ask?? I would venture to say that most of the population that has experienced LE had little clue as to the whys and reasons that we wear these lovely, hot, ugly sleeves before diagnosis!!!!!!  None of us asked for cancer but why waste time and energy getting upset about something so trivial as this "question"? Chattie

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2008 11:17PM Katiejane wrote: Doe,   The redness/cracked skin was just to the R of my clavicle, about 1.5 in .  It never entered my mind that my thyroid was being exposed enough to make a difference.  The Rad. Onc. told me the upper lobe of my R lung was going to get a tiny bit of exposure but that it was the only thing mentioned. I completed Rads. on Nov. 18th after 25 treatments. Prior, I had 4 tx. of chemo--A/C.  I had been feeling good until about a month ago.  I became extremely exhausted, sleeping 12-14 hrs. a night when I could, I was cold ALL of the time and after a summer of hot flashes it made no sense especially since I am on Arimidex. I had to force myself to eat and my face looked puffy to me.  Everyone kept telling me I was just "over doing it" and I needed to rest more!  I knew something wasn't right but this was a surprise.  Others may have different symptoms to share with all of us but that was it for me.  Oh, I did become allergic to Shrimp, breaking out in hives if I ate them(iodine). Christine, I did not have radio iodine tx. Allyson, Let us know what your Endo has to say. By the way, my THS was 134! Thanks for everyones input!     Chattie

Posts.Content: Katiejane wrote: Well, heres one I never thought of---rads. have damaged or destroyed my thyroid.  I ended up in the ER on Tuesday with a blood pressure of 210/106!!!!  My normal varied from 96/54 to 120/75.  Obviously the problem was there and it would have manifested itself in good time but I had a PET Scan about 10 days prior and the iodine radio isotopes they give you IV and was just too much for my system.  Now I know why I've been sooooooooooooo tired and could never seem to get warm!!!!!  They put me on Synthroid and a BP medication and I will see an Internal Medicine Doc on Monday. Has anyone else had this experience??  I would love to hear from you!!  And the Breast Cancer saga continues!!!!!!!!!!!!!  The good news is this is something easily dealt with!  Chattie Dx 6/13/2007 Dx 6/13/2007, ILC, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 3/28 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 1, 2012 05:46AM Katiejane wrote: Trisha,   I sure don't want to be the one to put a damper on Dr's Becker and Vasille but I have a friend who traveled to NYC and had a lymphnode transfer preformed by them this early spring.  She has primary lymphedema in one of her legs-the MRI found that her body is lacking many nodes that the normal system has.  I would have thought that a node mapping would have been preformed before moving forward w/ surgery but it was not.  The nodes that were harvested for the transfer were taken from the upper arm ON THE SAME SIDE as her leg LE!!! From a medical stand point I would think they should have used another harvest site and on the other side of her body.  Now she is starting to develop LE in her arm.  So now she does have atleast 1 patient who has developed LE in another area where there was none pre-op.  Please keep us posted on what you decide.

Good luck to you!    katiejane

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 04:35PM Katiejane wrote:   I am BRAC negative, extremely ER/PR positive(100% & 98%) with a family history of ovarian cancer (maternal aunt, maternal great aunt, and both of my mothers 1st cousins.) Every one of my doctor's were in favor of a hyster and ooph. I also wanted to rid my body of any source of hormone production! No question, I'd have the surgery. Mine was done vaginally so no exterior incisions. It's an easy surgery w/ easy recovery but remember, we all react differently. Katiejane
Posts.Title: Question for ER+ ladies.... Fearless_One Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Dec 30, 2010 06:31PM Katiejane wrote:   Fearless One,   Contrary to your opinion that I have a strong family history, I have been told for years that it was NOT a strong family Hx- and this was from many different doctors over many years. It was not a pressing matter is any of my Doc's opinions that I have the surgery but you really need to use your common sense-if you're ER/PR positive doesn't it make sense to do everything in your power to rid your body of one of the major hormone sources??? I felt it didn't take a rocket scientist to figure that one out.even if one doesn't have a family Hx. of ovarian cancer.
Posts.Title: Question for ER+ ladies.... Fearless_One Fearless_One

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 11:30PM Katiejane wrote:   My LE started in my R arm  and then went under the arm around to the back and chest.  My L arm is now beginning to swell -the upper part of the arm, under the arm and around the back & chest.  I don't remember it starting under the scar. It just started hurting in my arm one day and I have progressed from there.  I'm currently looking to get a Flexitouch Pump system to help. I do twice daily drainage massage and wear compression sleeves on both arms. I'm glad that you are being proactive-once you have LE, it never goes away. You just have to learn to manage it. You're on the right track!   Katiejane

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2008 11:49AM - edited Nov 11, 2008 11:49AM by Katiejane    Thanks Binney!   Activity levels are increasing and I am beginning to see a difference.  Had a LE massage last Friday, one again today, and one scheduled for this coming Friday.  I drink alot of fluids and my body lets me know if I haven't!!  It's weird how we all get to understand what our body will tell us because of this journey!  I am not one to sit around and have been cleared to return to work on Nov. 22nd. Posts.Content: Nov 15, 2008 10:13PM Katiejane wrote:    Hi everyone,      Well, I'm still having problems with this new swelling that developed 2.5 weeks after my hyster/ooph/bladder repair.  I've seen my LE therapist several times and continue to do my massage twice a day at home.  At my 2 week check with the GYN she said the mesh used for the sling was causing some erosion of tissue (vaginal) due to lack of estrogen. Much to my objections, she wanted me to use Estrase Vag Cream, .5-1 gram every other day for 2 weeks. This is suppose to help things heal and stop the erosion. It was either use it or loose the sling..   This will be the only time I will use this product.  With this chemo brain I now have, it just dawned on me that maybe the estrogen in the cream is causing the fluid retention??  I remember retaining 3-5lbs of fluids with every monthly cycle.  Any feedback?    Thanks,  katiejane
Posts.Title: LE Swelling Post-op Katiejane Katiejane

Posts.Content: Jan 5, 2010 05:37PM Katiejane wrote:   Just a quick FYI for anyone considering CT release surgery.  I saw my surgeon today and he has developed a way to do my "release" surgery without a tourniquet!  I hate to have surgery but am excited I may finally get relief!  He will leave my sutures in for alittle longer because of possible healing issues(LE) and I will receive IV antibiotics in the OR. PLease feel free to PM me if you have any questions.

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2008 11:04PM Katiejane wrote:   I was wondering which brand of compression vest your are being fitted with?  I was fitted w/ the Solaris Tribute Vest for Truncal LE, a nightime garment but it has never fit correctly even after they altered  the width.  Seems I don't tolerate pressure from the underarm area of the vest and it feels very sore and bruised after.  Really inflames that area.  Good luck!

Posts.Title: Jan 2008--Ain't it Great? Determined1 Diana63

Posts.Content: Katiejane wrote:   On Oct 22nd I had a hysterectomy, oopherectomy, & bladder sling surgery. I have arm & truncal LE and was allowed to wear my compression sleeves/gauntlets into the OR. They even allowed me to position my arms and neck before they knocked me out. IV was started in my foot (temporary) so that I could be put to sleep when another IV was placed in my neck.(the foot access was d/c'd.) Now that I'm 2.5 weeks out from surgery, my LE has started to swell more than it has in a very long time.  I have continued with my massages here at home and with my therapist. Nothing has changed other than my activity level. I really believe this may be the cause of this flare up but it scares me just the same.  Does anyone have any other ideas as to why I might be swelling?  Thanks for any input.    katiejane    P.S.   All bp's were taken in my legs. Dx 6/13/2007 Dx 6/13/2007, ILC, Stage IIA, Grade 3, 3/28 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2016 11:27PM Katiejane wrote: Chrystalphm, Did you have the cortisone injection for your shoulder???? What type of results did you have? I hope it was a positive outcome for you! Katiejane
Posts.Title: Can I get a cortisone shot in affected arm? BayouBabe crystalphm

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2017 03:05PM Katiejane wrote: Maria, I have a completely torn rotator cuff on my LE arm. My LE extends under my arm and completely around my back and chest to the other arm. I have seen 2 different Ortho's regarding the pain and possible surgery to repair my rotator cuff. I also spoke to my surgeon who did my DIEP and lymph node transfer. One surgeon said it wouldn't be a risk to have surgery or and injection, one surgeon said no way-he would not do surgery or an injection, and my reconstruction surgeon spoke to many Ortho's in her area and all said they would never do either procedure on a LE patient--period! I have chosen to live with the pain and limited use of my arm. Unfortunately, if I over use my arm it swells from the shoulder inflammation on top of my LE swelling. Kind of a no win situation but I have accepted it and moved on. Just another gift from the cancer journey! I wish you well and please let us know what you decide and the outcome! Best of luck!!! Katiejane
Posts.Title: steroid injection for shoulder burstitis and LE risk maria26 JO-5

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2007 07:14PM Katiejane wrote: Chemomom,  Like you, I had a bi-lateral mastectomy(1 prophylactic, 1 necessary) in June of '07 and have chosen to not have reconstruction.  I had 36 C's before BC and to be honest there are times I wish I still had breasts but I'm not willing to go through more surgeries.  I have my " boobs in a box" in my closet but have chosen not to wear them. I have no problem with a flat chest but my cloths do fit differently. People who haven't been through this can't understand why I have chosen not to do reconstruction.  Many don't understand that implants aren't just a 1 time surgery.  For me, comfort is the name of the game! Who knows, maybe down the road I'll stuff some tissues in my prosthesis bra! The silicone prosthesis are much to heavy!!!   Chattie
Posts.Title: No reconstruction- Happy w/your decision? marlee1 quietpools

Posts.Content: Dec 9, 2009 10:15PM Katiejane wrote:     Have any of you ladies actually had carpal tunnel surgery?  I have posted about this before and had decided to postpone reduction surgery for fear of LE inflammation.   My CTS has worsened and I fear it will permanently damage the nerves.  My hands tingle constantly and frequently become so numb that I have to stop whatever I'm doing and reposition my hands. I have looked into the "open reduction" as well as the reduction done w/a scope.   Any feedback ????  Thanks ! Katiejane

Posts.Content: Jan 18, 2011 12:35AM Katiejane wrote:  I have LE in both arms, trunk, and back. It definitely feels like deep bruising.  It also can feel very sore and tight when I have a flare. My skin is hypersensitive and I have a difficult time with many fabrics rubbing against the area from my armpits around to my back. I didn't have reconstruction and have just made the final decision that I never will as I know it will only make my pain worse-and I cant imagine how painful a bra with prosthesis would be so I've chosen the natural look!  :) Boyzbeebs,  Ativan is not a pain medication. It is prescribed for anxiety.
Posts.Title: can you describe what truncal LE pain feels like? minxie ktym

Posts.Content: Dec 1, 2008 05:52PM Katiejane wrote:    Ulla,  I don't know if you remember me---I came on this board just a month or so before you. At that time I went by the name Chattie and had just finished chemo after bilateral mastectomy. At that time you were telling me that you weren't going to tell your mother( who was back in your home country) about the diagnosis due to their circumstances with the war.  I have thought about you often and have wondered how you are doing??!! I understand the feelings you're experiencing and it seems to hit all of us to one degree or another.  You will figure out how to cope and things do get better.  I find the busier I am, the better I fell. I'm also one who needs to keep my mind occupied otherwise I become anxious, sad, and tearful.  Sounds kind of crazy but that's just the way it is.  I hope you are doing well!!! Katiejane(aka Chattie)
Posts.Title: please help sueps barbe1958

Posts.Content: Katiejane wrote:   I have truncal LE and my LE therapist ordered a Solaris Tribute vest for night wear.  Last night was the first time I have slept with the vest on .  Today is the first day I have gotten up with my back feeling the way it use to before BC!!!!!!!!!!!  It obviously did what it was suppose to do as I don't have that tight, uncomfortable feeling across my back and around the under arm area!!!!!  It did a fantastic job with the fluid!  Binney, thanks for recommending the vest.  I will be wearing it in Sept. when I fly to visit family.  Question is, do you put in on before you pass through security or after??  Also, is it effective to wear over a shirt or does it need to be under your shirt against your skin?  I really don't want to be pulled aside at security!  Thanks in advance for any input!
